video.title: Learn Flask for Python - Full Tutorial
video.description:
Flask is a micro web framework written in Python. It is classified as a microframework because it does not require particular tools or libraries. Learn how to use it in this crash course tutorial.

💻Code: https://github.com/jakerieger/FlaskIntroduction

Tutorial from Jake Rieger. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0np-tFaO8GPJuIKZhwnQxg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Jonathan Bruce
topLevelComment.text:
when trying to create the database, I get this error:

>>> from app import db
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/jb/Desktop/pyTodoApp/app.py", line 10, in <module>
    class Todo(db.Model):
  File "/Users/jb/Desktop/pyTodoApp/app.py", line 11, in Todo
    id = db.Column(db.Interger, primary_key=True)
  File "/Users/jb/Desktop/pyTodoApp/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/flask_sqlalchemy/extension.py", line 988, in __getattr__
    raise AttributeError(name)
AttributeError: Interger

this has occurred with other tutorials as well, so what am I missing?

replies.author: Jonathan Bruce
replies.text: nevermind , noticed I was spelling "interger" like I hear so many say it, with an extra 'r' , which was causing the error.

>>> app.app_context().push()
>>> db.create_all()

Happy hacking :)

topLevelComment.author: Sean
topLevelComment.text:
For us windows nubs having trouble running the environment:

To install :
pip install --user virtualenv

To create a virtual environment (env):
python -m virtualenv env

To activate:
-env\Scripts\activate

to deactivate:
-deactivate

replies.text:
I figured it out! 
The  problem was that i have installed Anaconda and did set it as my default interpreter for my terminal in vs code.

Solution : 1) UNINSTALL ANACONDA
                  2) UNINSTALL PYTHON
                  3) Reinstall Python and set its path in environment variables.
                  4) open VS CODE and select python interpreter.
                  5) pip should work in VS CODE.
                  6) Reinstall ANACONDA but don't set it as default path for third party IDEs

topLevelComment.author: Kari Rovala
topLevelComment.text:
@5:43
On Windows It's '\env\Scripts\activate.bat'

Ran into many errors trying to setup the virtual environment. 
It took a minute to understad the errors, I am running Windows.

When you try to run a Powershell script (ps1), you may face error File cannot be 
loaded because running scripts is disabled on this system. This error may appear 
in Powershell, but also in ISE or Visual Studio Code (VS Code).

final solution: https://www.itexperience.net/fix-file-cannot-be-loaded-because-running-scripts-is-disabled-on-this-system/

used the following code in the terminal to setup virtual environment:
.\\env\Scripts\activate

The TERMINAL changes to '(env)' that tells me the virtual environment is active.
(env) PS C:\Users\Ghost\PycharmProjects\FlaskIntroduction>

topLevelComment.author: Kari Rovala

When linking the stylesheet on line 7 the code reads:


<link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ url_for('static', filename='css/main.css') }}">


I went with a different code on line 7 to link the stylesheet. Here is my code on line 7:


<link rel="stylesheet" href="../static/css/main.css">


This both lines of code achieve the same thing.

virtualenv install for windows 10:
open up terminal in VS Code
1)pip install --upgrade virtualenv                         press enter
2) virtualenv env                                                     press enter
3) virtualenv \path\to\env\Scripts\activate      press enter

For windows 10 you must use 'virtualenv ...' to run commands. Example: 'virtualenv \path\to\env\bin\activate' to activate.

topLevelComment.author: Ellie
topLevelComment.text: thank you for the great tutorial! there're couple questions if anyone can please help, I accidentally added a task without any content, it worked, thought since in class Todo() content=(nullable=False), it shouldn't let me do that, right? also changed db.String(200) to db.String(5) to test it out, but it let me add text more than 5 characters, why? thank you again in advance!

replies.author: Anton Grouchtchak
replies.text:
A bit late, but maybe others will see:

When a task without content is added, it is stored in the database as "", an empty string, which does not equal to Null.
Regarding character limit, SQLite does not enforce column lengths.

If you want to enforce these limits, you have to do it manually in Python.

topLevelComment.text:
can you create tutorial on simple user management system in flask something like this -------------------------
I have the following tables:

Table name= group Attributes:

id name

Here simply the group is created.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Table name = group permission

 Attributes: id group_id Permission_id

Here simply the permission for the group is assigned 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Table name =permission
 Attributes: id name code name

Here permission is created Table name =user Attributes: id username password
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here the user is created

Table name =user_groups 
Attributes: Id User_id Group_id

Here the group for the user is assigned and all the permission inside this group should also be assigned to that user 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Table name =user_permission 
Attributes: Id User_id Permission_id

Here the user might get more permission other than the permission assigned from the group.

For example, if the user has only access for reading and writes from it’s defined group then if the admin user wants then he/she can directly assign permission to access a certain menu to the specific user without assigning to the other user of the same group.

I haven't seen anyone on youtube have done this stuff

topLevelComment.author: Arnob Chowdhury
topLevelComment.text:
If the virtual environment is showing error like:
"" + CategoryInfo: SecurityError: (:) [], PSSecurityException
   + FullyQualifiedErrorId : UnauthorizedAccess """
1. Open powershell with "Run as Administrator"
2. execute this: "Get-ExecutionPolicy -List"
3. if currentUser is Undefined then
3.1. execute "Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned"
then try  ".\env\Scripts\activate.ps1"
You are good to go!

replies.author: Da Ju
replies.text:
i had the same problem.  i finally solved it by deleting my virtualenv by:
1) type deactivate in the terminal
2) delete the env folder in VS Code
3) create a new virtual environment by typing virtualenv newenv   ...  this gives it a new name so you're sure it's not the old one
4) type source newenv/bin/activate now you should see "newenv" on the left in the terminal
5) then type pip3 install flask flask-sqlalchemy and this should install them in the new virtual environment.
6) then erase the test.db folder in VS Code
7) then type python3 to go into a python terminal
8) type from app import db
9) type db.drop_all()
10) type db.create_all()


You should now see a new test.db file created.  It should work now.  If not, you most likely have a typo somewhere.

topLevelComment.author: Hamza Akbar
topLevelComment.text:
Those using Python3 don't have to install virtualenv via pip. Python3 already has a package venv package that you can use to create virtual environments. 
So to create a virtual environment with the venv package type "python -m venv virtual-environment-name". Note that this command should be without the quotes I've added to mark the command. Also enter the command when you are in the directory where you want to create the virtual enviroment.
To activate the virtual environment type "environment-name\Scripts\activate". And to deactivate the environment type, deactivate. 
This guy in the tutorial is not wrong, but he's doing it with an external package that Python2 users will have to use; Python3 users don't have to do the same way

topLevelComment.author: Lying Cat
topLevelComment.text:
Good tutorial and a quick rundown of Flask, perfect for my needs :) thank you. But even though I’m more of a backend guy, hard coding that in-line style on that h1 tag at 31:05 made me cringe a little. I know this isn’t a CSS tutorial but showing bad CSS practices to new coders is probably not great, unless it’s unavoidable or at least with a warning.

Quickly for non CSS people, in-line styles can make your CSS very hard to maintain as the app grows. As you cannot override in-line from a CSS file with out using !important which is also bad practice to use. CSS is challenging enough, don’t make it more so.

replies.author: Lucaischz
replies.text: I actually think it would be better to use __str__() other than __repr__() as it's not going to be the exact representation of the class, which should be Todo().

replies.author: Kelvin Omereshone
replies.text: Percentages are Jinja2 syntax

replies.author: sarath kumar
replies.text: @ARKSYN Thank you the brackets confused me

replies.author: ARKSYN
replies.text: All that line does is return a printable representation of the Todo class we created. The percent is Python syntax for string interpolation where '%r' is the placeholder and the '% self.id' is what will replace the '%r'. In this case we're just printing: <Task self.id> where id is the id of the Todo object we just created. The brackets are just for formatting they aren't necessary.

replies.author: ARKSYN

Completed is never used. You don't need that line. If you look at the code on GitHub it should be:

class Todo(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    content = db.Column(db.String(200), nullable=False)
    date_created = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

replies.author: Free Grace Toronto
replies.text: you can run any language on the back end.  The web used to be powered by Perl scripts running in the back end. Now it's Javascript through Node and other frameworks, and Python through Django and Flask back end frameworks. it runs on the back end, not in the browser, that's the big difference. so you can do stuff like templates and routing on the back end, then the server renders those into regular HTML/CSS/JS that the browser can run
